Subjective: Spot on neck for 2 weeks. Started as a small wound after shaving or an insect bite. Became swollen and redder. Itches. Intermittent scabs form and fall off. No pain. No other similar spots on body. PMH: Warts, ear abscess removal. FH: Paternal family history of sun-related skin problems on head (grandfather, uncles), specific type unknown. Social: No smoking/alcohol mentioned. ICE: Worried about skin cancer after online search; wants lesion removed, prefers freezing.
Objective: Neck: Single raised, pinkish-red lesion, approx. 0.5 cm, with a redder spot in the center. No visible scab or flaking currently. Surrounding skin has some freckles. No cervical lymphadenopathy.
Assessment: Undiagnosed neck lesion. Differential diagnosis includes pyogenic granuloma vs. atypical mole. Awaiting dermatology opinion.
Plan: 1. Take photo of lesion and send for dermatology e-consultation. 2. Discussed potential removal methods: cryotherapy (freezing), excision, or curettage with histology. 3. Await dermatologist's advice before proceeding. 4. Follow-up: Clinician to call patient on Friday (before 10 am or after 3 pm) with dermatologist's plan. Voicemail will be left if unreachable. 5. Patient advised to make a separate appointment for unrelated knee pain.
